messageBody:
Hi Lothar,

First off, I wanted to mention, a lot of my tests can be automated, albeit with delays or polling. But, I suppose what I could do, is create some code that does a DB insert/update, that simulates what the nightly job does, without actually doing all the work. In other words, take some data that I'm expecting, and put it in the DB, rather than actually "generate" the data. That way, I don't need the nightly job to be part of the testing cycle.

Then, all the tests could run independently, and not rely on each other, but I could also run them in order manually, to verify that the system actually works as a whole. Then, I could actually have an "OrderedTest" that instantiates all my TestCase classes, and calls them in order. That in itself would then be it's own separate test.

Does that sound like a good idea?

Anyhow, I respond to your comments below.

----- "Lothar Kimmeringer" <maillists_job@...> wrote:
> From: "Lothar Kimmeringer" <maillists_job@...>
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Sent: Monday, August 17, 2009 1:27:27 AM GMT -07:00 US/Canada Mountain
> Subject: Re: [junit] Dependency Testing
>





>
> > The reason I ask is because this is what is basically happening: There
> > is an external ASYNCHRONOUS SOAP messaging system that is the core to
> > all communication between several companies. Requests/responses can be
> > sent to and from all of the participating parties. For testing purposes,
> > so that my tests can be a little more controlled, I send requests and
> > responses to and from my own server. i.e. I do not send to other
> > companies, because I cannot guarantee they will respond within the time
> > I need (seconds), even though technically, their test systems are
> > supposed to be up and running.
>
> If you abstracted the layer between your applicaiton and the messaging
> system you can simply define a mock that answers the requests for you.
> That way you don't need to setup anything in advance. I'm doing this
> here e.g. for testing the parts of our software doing OFTP by ISDN.




Yes, that would be possible, but also a whole heck of a lot of extra work. It would probably double the code, perhaps even more. I was trying to keep my part of the application simple. :D




Also, by doing this, I am still circumventing the testing that actually tests to see if the system actually works. And, I don't want to do that, as I want to be sure the system actually works, and not just my code. I could do these little abstractions (with a factory, that has test and production configurations), and that would test my code, but it would not test that my code works with the other system, as I would end up having a "fake" layer, pretending to be their system, but never actually verifying.





>
> > 1. submit request to my system, through the external system. This is
> > effectively to test receiving requests from the external system, to me.
> > i.e. I can send requests to myself, as if they were coming from someone
> > else's system.
> > 2. receive request from external system
> > 3. queue job for nightly build of data
> > 4. check for available data from nightly job, the next day
> > 5. send available data
> > 6. receive the data sent in #5, and email it out to a staff member
>
> For this I see Ant or Maven a better fitting tool than JUnit. There
> you have dependencies and all the things you need for data-transfer,
> emailing, etc.




I am using Maven, but maven isn't a testing tool. However, it does support JUnit.




>
> So write an Ant script that is preparing everything as needed and
> start e.g. the JUnit-tests that do the testing. With the optional
> tasks junit and junitreport you even end up with a nice HTML-page
> similar to a Java-API documentation showing you what tests failed
> and what succeeded. Combined e.g. with Cobertura you can see what
> parts of your application aren't under test.
>
> Regards, Lothar
>
>
